item.title: hurricane on the outside, sun dress weather inside
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Sundress Weather. It is a beautiful thing. Someone should do research on the psychological effects of good weather on the floral prints lobe of the brain. Seriously. Why am I writing about Sundress Weather amidst a torrential downpour as hurricane Irene slowly but menacingly makes its way up the East coast? Because Sundress Weather is brief. Sundress Weather is fleeting. Sundress Weather is that small gap between when all the Frisbees start flying out on campus and when your ice cream liquefies before you even get to take a bite. The rest of the year is t-shirt and leggings weather. Spend 10 minutes getting ready in the morning (7 of them on trying to find that damn problem set I most definitely finished, I think…) weather. Trying not to hit people with my unwieldy bag of books weather. Unfortunately, the rest of the year also happens to coincide with my entire time at school, where I get to live with some of my greatest friends in what is no doubt the greatest city in the world. And, yes, try to survive midterms and projects and finals, all while constantly trying to remind convince myself that it’s doing me good. Which is why, inspired by my talented and tech-savvy friend Amrita, I’m going to embark on a little fashion project. Because even if it is a-hurricaine-ing outside, it never hurts to bring a little Sundress Weather inside.
black halter leotard, white skirt, cowboy boots, gold hoop earrings
Here’s the plan:
  • Every Friday, for one semester (or longer if it turns out well!) I’ll post my most inspired outfit of the week on Mon Petit Chou. That way, I’ll be forced to get out of my t-shirt, even if it is just once a week. J

And for reference, here are a few of my thoughts on fashion…

  • I do not consider myself a very fashionable person. As in, although I like looking at magazines for inspiration and admire fashion as an art, I don’t really keep on top of fashion trends or make dressing up a huge part of my life. So my outfits will just be based on whatever I feel works well in my closet, plus whatever inspires me at the moment!
  • Minimalism and simplicity are very important to me. When I dress, I look for colors, patterns, shapes and cuts that work together well. I really don’t accessorize much.
  • I am a very petite person (hence Mon Petit Chou), and I try to wear things that suit my body. Therefore, my outfits may not work for everyone! On the other hand, featured in magazines and on mannequins may not always be the best for me.
  • Finally, please do keep in mind that I am not a very dress-up sort of girl. I don’t wear makeup on a daily basis, and as stated above, I spend about 10 minutes on average getting ready in the morning. But I hope you will find my outfits inspiring, and that you will inspire me to dress for sunny moods more often!

P.S.: In other exciting news, Mon Petit Chou just needs 2 more likes to reach the 100-fan mark on Facebook! Maybe you will be lucky user 100? Check it out-- it’s a great way to keep tabs on what’s cooking if you’re a Facebook user.

P.P.S. Hope everyone stays indoors and safe in the stormy weather. Keep your fingers crossed for New York and the Tri-State area.

item.title: the Peanut Butter Club
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
So. I have a job. Actually, this post is a little too late, because by the time you read it, i'll probably be well into my last day. No, I didn't get fired in record time; I've actually been interning since May, but like the boxes that remain stacked in the basement since I packed them up in the last overnighter of the semester (apparently I have enough shoes to fill a cardboard crate + 2 large tote bags? good to know!), my blogging to-do list seems to pile higher and higher, mostly gathering dust as well, hence the late introduction. It's been a priceless experience. Although sitting at a desk for 40 hours a week (plus commuting 3 hours every day) took some time to get used to (up until then, my idea of work was comprised of a) sweating my ass off at a dance studio being yelled at by some angry lady in a Russian accent, or b) spending hours cross-legged in sweats and glasses alternating between cramming physics into my brain and Starbucks doubleshots into my mouth to make up for all those times I choose sleep over lecture (and no, I don't regret any of them)), OMGPOP has one of the friendliest company cultures that i've encountered. Although I did not have the chance to do any technical work*, getting to know an incredibly talented (and funny) team was definitely the best part and made it all worthwhile, and then some. Plus, when else do you get to play games during work? Oh, and did I mention that Soho is a restaurant mecca? And that I got to try out a new place every Thursday, thanks to an awesome company-bonding event? But sometimes, the most fun and delicious lunches were created right in the office. Without further ado, I present the Peanut Butter Club! (This week's theme was Fruity Mexican. Whether that is a reference to a person or the tortillas we used to fill up with pb, chocolate, and all sorts of berries, I'll let you decide.)

Goodbye OMGPOP! Goodbye (for now), New York! I will be back to visit, surely. *Speaking of which, summer job number 2 starts on Monday, and it involves writing computer programs to sort data from the web. So it is technical indeed. It also sounds a little scary, but, like Nike said, Just Do It™. P.S.: I'm breaking my golden rule of never posting photos of people, this is how much I love you, OMGPOP.

item.title: Budget Bites & Avocado Melt
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
This year, as a sophomore, I am no longer required to subscribe to one of the University's extremely expensive & less-than-gourmet meal plans, hooray! Although my overall budget allowance for food has shrunk drastically, to be honest, I'm loving it.

It probably has to do with the fact that I absolutely detest being told what to do (I went on a cruise in Norway last year…and was miserable. Assigned tables, mealtimes, forget it! The fjords were quite lovely, though.) and would rather eat a good old pbj on my time than wait in line to get a plateful of mass-prepared mush.

Nonetheless, living on $100 a month for groceries is no easy feat in New York City. Perhaps even more difficult is limiting my "fun" fund (restaurant/Starbucks/froyo budget) to the same amount. To help document the process, and make it more fun, I've created a new category called "budget bites" (you can access all the categories on the right sidebar!) where I'll share some of the cheap, easy, and good eats that I make with limited resources and equipment. Since it's already hard enough to keep healthy at school, most will be on the lighter side as well and probably vegetarian (I eat meat, but seldom cook it, and prefer vegetarian cuisine a lot of the time).

Without further ado, here's one of my favorite new discoveries!

Avocado Melt Serves 1

  • 1 whole grain tortilla
  • 1 slice Munster cheese (my favorite for it’s meltability & mild & creamy taste, but you can use whatever you’d like!)
  • ¼ ripe avocado, sliced
  • Dijon mustard, to taste

1. Spread some mustard over tortilla, and top with cheese and avocado. 2. Fold over to enclose filling, and microwave on High for 30 seconds. 3. Eat warm and melty!

It doesn't get any easier than this. 30 seconds of cooking for gooey, cheesy, avocado bliss!

item.title: japanese cooking with my cousin!
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
My awesome cousin Alice and I are both sorta obsessed with Japanese culture.

Last winter we were lucky enough to visit Tokyo for a trip-of-a-lifetime before the earthquake and tsunami sadly devastated the beautiful country. The food was absolutely amazing! Everything was made with eye to detail and presentation. Sushi in the US really can't compare! I always feel like rice in American restaurants is never quite made right. I would love to go back one day, but for now, we'll have to make do with our own homemade sushi and okonomiyaki!

item.title: crazy for cocoa puffs
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Cocoa banana pancake puffs, that is. Each little two-bite ebelskiver is bursting with gooey banana and chocolate flavor. Just describing them makes me want to make them, now. I'm absolutely loving the new ebelskiver pan. Can't wait to stir up new flavor combinations! Tomorrow is Saturday. And Sunday comes afterwards... Are you gonna add some FUN FUN FUN to your breakfast?* Cocoa Banana Pancake Puffs Makes 7 mini puffs (perfect for a weekend breakfast or brunch!)
  • 1/4 c + 2 T whole wheat flour
  • 2 T cocoa powder
  • 1 t baking powder
  • 1 T sugar
  • a dash of cinnamon
  • a pinch of salt
  • 1/2 c soymilk
  • 1 t vegetable oil
  • banana slices
  1. Grease ebelskiver pan liberally and preheat over a medium flame.
  2. In a large cereal bowl, mix together flour, cocoa, baking powder, sugar, cinnamon, and salt. Pour in soymilk and oil, and stir just until combined.
  3. Drop a tablespoon of batter into each indent, top with a banana slice, and cover with a bit more batter. Cook for 3-5 min, until edges are set, and flip over with chopsticks/tool of choice. Cook 2-3 min more, and carefully remove. Serve warm. Watch your mood miraculously improve.

*I have now had the wretched song stuck in my head for 20 minutes and counting. Forgive me, O God of Puns, for I have sinned.

item.title: on stereotypes and hello kitty cookies
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: There is a common stereotype that stereotypes are bad. Sometimes it feels like I spend a lot of my day and a lot of my life fighting against them. Plant-lover, but not a tree-hugger. City girl, small town roots. Cupcake-making, kitten-obsessed feminist. Bookworm, writer, engineer. (For the record SEAS can read!*) Sometimes, it can get rather tiring. Sometimes, you're not sure whether to be pleased you've fooled them so well or punch the next person in the face who exclaims: "You're an engineer? I thought you were an English major!" Read: because you're a girl and you don't have four-inch glasses. No way! But just between you and me, stereotypes exist for a reason. Sometimes they're kind of true. Sometimes I even endorse them. Hello my name is small Asian girl, and Hello Kitty makes me happy. Especially in cookie form. Bonus points for pink-ness and tiny-ness. Kthxbai. Cookie recipe adapted from Baking Bites *SEAS = School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. "SEAS can't read" is a joke I've heard floating around campus. It infuriates me to no end.

item.title: super mario 'shroomcakes!
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
It's Super Mario...

'shroom cakes!

If you haven't guessed already, I'm a bit of a Super Mario geek. I just love the sheer creativity of the games. Nothing says childhood like playing the Original Super Mario Bros on my cousin's hand-me-down dog-chewed NES.

Here's a quick and clever little recipe for Mini Mario 'Shroomcakes! It's really more of a concept. So easy and adorable. It'd be great for a child's birthday party. Or a not-child's birthday party.Or perhaps to give your friend a Power-up? We could all use one of those.

1-UP AND POWER-UP CAKES

Makes 24 mini-shrooms

• ½ batch of your favorite White or Yellow Cake Batter • ½ batch of your Favorite Frosting • white chocolate chips, for decoration (at most, 1 cup) • red and green food coloring • black marker

1. This is more of a concept than a recipe! And a very cute one at that. 2. Line a mini-muffin tin with paper cups and fill them about ½ full with batter. Bake for approx. 10 min, or until risen and firm. Move cakes to a wire rack and let them cool completely. 3. Meanwhile, prepare the buttercream according to instructions. Spoon into two bowls; add red food coloring to one, and green food coloring to the other. You want a nice vibrant color. 4. When cupcakes are cool, frost with color of choice, and stick a few white chocolate chips, pointy-side down, into frosting to make the spots. Use the marker to draw two little eyes on the paper liner. Voila!

item.title: banana oatmeal cookie pancakes
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
These pancakes from Chocolate Covered Katie taste like one part oatmeal cookie + one part caramelized banana + one part melted chocolate. Last time I checked, that equation = the perfect way to start your weekend. Banana Oatmeal Cookie Pancakes (Vegan) Makes 1 large serving, about 3 pancakes adapted from Chocolate Covered Katie
  • 1/3 cup white whole wheat flour
  • 1/3 cup oatmeal
  • 1 t vanilla
  • 1 T brown sugar
  • 1 t cinnamon
  • 1/8 tsp salt
  • 1 t baking powder
  • 1/2 cup soymilk
  • 1/2 banana, sliced
  • 1/4 cup chocolate chips
  1. Lightly grease a skillet and preheat over medium heat.
  2. Meanwhile, stir together all dry ingredients in a bowl, and all the wet in another. Add the wet into the dry and stir just to combine. Stir in chocolate chips.
  3. Ladle about ¼ cups of batter onto preheated skillet and top each pancake with a few slices of banana. Cook for 2-3 min. or until bubbles form along the top and edges are firm. Flip and cook for another 2-3 min.
  4. Serve warm.
Note: the original recipe from Chocolate Covered Katie contains no added oil, but if you're not watching your fat intake, I'd add 1 tsp oil to the batter for more moist pancakes (and hey, there's plenty of chocolate so you might as well give in, right?).

item.title: i'm in love.
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: with my new iPhone. love. love. love like this:                   I have a habit of falling in love with things that are not boys. Or people, for that matter. But that is another point. It's a love that leaves my half-done discrete math problem set in a heap on the kitchen table. A love that leaves my trusty steed, the good old Canon, crying in the drawer. A love that makes an extreme bookworm put down her reading. Now that's saying a lot. To be fair, it wasn't the only reason I missed out on Fashion Friday yesterday--it's Fall Break (finally! I've had it up to my ears with schoolwork) for Columbia, and the line at Port Authority turned out to be ridiculously delayed, so by the time I got home, I was in no state for a photo shoot. Will you take a cookie as an apology? Do not be fooled by their "healthy" facade. They may be vegan and butterless, but these cookies are ADDICTIVE. The fact that they're loaded with chocolate chips may or may not help. Chewy, moist, soft and full of pumpkin flavor, it's like pumpkin pie in a cookie. With chocolate. Perfect for the holidays, which (I can hardly believe) are coming up! And try to restrain yourself from devouring all the raw batter, which tastes exactly like pumpkin pie. In cookie dough form. 'Nuff said. Can you tell I'm in love? Ridiculously Addictive Pumpkin Chocolate Chip Cookies (Vegan) Adapted from SparkPeople Makes 2 dozen medium-large cookies • 2 c flour • 1 t baking soda • 1 t baking powder • 1 t cinnamon • ¼ t salt • 1 c brown sugar • 1 c pumpkin puree • ½ c unsweetened applesauce • 1 c chocolate chips 1. Preheat oven to 350F and line two cookie sheets. 2. In a medium bowl, mix flour, baking soda, baking powder, cinnamon, and salt. 3. In a large bowl, combine sugar, pumpkin, applesauce. Stir in the dry mixture until just combined; fold in chocolate chips. 4. Drop large spoonfulls of batter onto cookie sheet. 5. Bake for about 15 min, or until puffed and firm on top. P.S. To sweeten the deal, if you're on campus, stop by my room for a sample ! :)

item.title: honey pumpkin cornbread & shortcut chili
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: Halloween is coming up right around the corner, which means…it's officially pumpkin season! Unfortunately, it's also the start of (never-ending) midterm season, which means that things can get quite haphazard, to say the least. To celebrate a rare calm between deadlines and exams, I stirred up this hearty (and healthy!) bean chili, a stick-to-your-ribs rainy-day meal (perfect for hungry college students!). To go with it, I adapted Lindsay's cornbread recipe from the Happy Herbivore Cookbook to make it pumpkin (of course!) and honey flavored. I was a little skeptical, since it was not only vegan but fat free, but it was absolutely heavenly! So moist and sweet. Definitely the best cornbread recipe I've ever made. If you have Lindsay's book, the recipe for cornbread is on page 49. Just substitute pumpkin puree for the applesauce, and honey for the maple syrup, if you're not vegan. No need for extra sugar! Look at that Smart Balance shmear, mmm... Shortcut Bean Chili Serves 4 • 1 16-oz can kidney beans (or any sort of beans!) • 1 16-oz can crushed tomatoes • 1 green pepper, diced • ½ sweet onion, diced • 1 t cumin • EVOO 1. In a medium saucepan, cook onions in olive oil until nice and caramelized. Stir in green peppers, and cook until tender. 2. Stir in remaining ingredients, and simmer over low heat until heated through. 3. Serve warm, with cheese and Honey-Pumpkin Cornbread. P.S. Guess what came in the mail for me yesterday? A Hello Kitty Thermos! Yes, it's ridiculously pink, and yes, it cheers me up immensely. Can't wait to bring my chili in it to work :)

item.title: budget bites: magic peanut sauce
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
I swear, this sauce is like magic: put it anything from tofu to chicken to rice to noodles (cold peanut noodles, mmm!) to crudités for an instant pick-me-up! And so easy too.

Magic Peanut Sauce

(So this isn't really a recipe, I know...but you really don't need one, I swear! Just eyeball it and give it a taste...trust me :) The amounts are up to you! )

  • creamy peanut butter
  • soy sauce
  • vinegar
  • sugar or honey
  • hot water
  1. In a small bowl, combine peanut butter, soy sauce, vinegar, sugar/honey (all to taste). Slowly add hot water until you reach a pourable consistence.
  2. Use as a sauce, dip, or marinade!

Pictured above is one of my favorite busy weeknight meals: steamed broccoli, tofu, and the aforementioned sauce!

item.title: budget bites: hummus & tomato tartine
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Schoolwork has definitely been amping up to full volume now and that in combination with attempts to keep a small budget is my excuse for the lack of creative/real recipes lately.

But  sometimes simpler is better!

Here was a quick lunch I had last week: sundried tomato hummus and fresh tomatoes on a slice of baguette. (Tartine is just a fancy French word for open-face sandwich! Sounds nice, doesn't it?)

The best part?

It was almost completely free. I had worked an event at the Deutsches Haus that night and got to take all the yummy leftover hors d'oeuvres home: fresh baguettes, cheese, and this lovely hummus (I adore sundried tomatoes!).

Not much of a recipe, but it was delicious!

item.title: pumpkin chocolate chip oats in a jar
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Have you heard of the desserts-in-a-jar trend lately?

I think it's such a adorable and clever idea! Although nothing can beat the timelessness of a good old slab of chocolate layer cake, there's just something so charming and kitschy about glass jars. I'm quite a fan of them.

Spicy, warm, and comforting, this simple recipe is the perfect fall day treat. Stir it up in an old peanut butter jar like I did and you have a healthy and delicious breakfast (or dessert!) on the go.

Pumpkin Chocolate Chip Oats in a Jar Makes 1 serving -1/2 c instant oatmeal -1/2-1 c boiling water -1/4 c pumpkin puree (use the good stuff! Organic tastes better :) ) -splash of milk or soy milk -dash of cinnamon -handful of chocolate chips

Put the oatmeal in your jar or bowl, and pour boiling water over it (the amount depends on how thick you like it--I like mine nice and gooey). Now here's the hard part: let it sit for at least 10 minutes. The longer you let it sit, the thicker it will be. You could use the microwave or even a saucepan if you are impatient like me or you want to use old fashioned or steel cut oats, both of which are delicious. Once your oats are nice and thick, stir in the the pumpkin, a splash of milk, and the cinnamon. Sprinkle chocolate chips, give it a good stir, and savor with a cup of tea.

Isn't this pumpkin so vibrant and lovely?

item.title: rainy day veggie roast
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: It's one of those Saturdays: rainy, drowsy, chilly. A day to get up at noon, and spend the day holed up in the library (well, until you get kicked out for eating cookies. theoretically.). A day to try out that new drip coffee at Joe's. A day to make this super easy (literally throw into the oven and walk away!) and economical dinner. A perfect dinner to enjoy in rainy Saturday peace…Now if only the frat next door would refrain from blasting the dub step and shouting at the top of their lungs… Rainy Day BBQ Tofu & Veggie Roast Makes 3 hearty servings • 1 block extra firm tofu, cubed • about ½ cup BBQ sauce • 2 large potatoes, cut into thick fries • large bunch of broccoli, floreted • salt, pepper, olive oil 1. Preheat oven to 400°F (see note). Grease two baking sheets. 2. In separate bowls, toss broccoli & potatoes with oil until well coated. Mix together tofu & BBQ sauce in a third bowl. 3. Put the veggies into one baking sheet, spreading them all out, and sprinkle with salt and pepper. 4. Pour tofu onto another sheet. 5. Bake for 20-30 min, or until tender and browned. 6. Enjoy! Note: The oven in my dorm kitchen is a little wonky and tends to underheat so I ended up roasting everything for about 30-40 min, and sadly, the veggies didn't get as crisp and caramelized as they ought to. Next time i'm upping it to 425° and seeing how it goes, but if you are on peaceful terms with your own oven, 400° for 20-30 min. should be just fine and dandy. Adding it All Up: • organic extra firm tofu: 2.49 • 2 idaho potatoes: 1.26 • large bunch of broccoli: 1.67 • organic BBQ sauce (for the whole bottle): 2.99 For 3 meals (and not measly portions either!), the whole thing costs $8.41—which makes it just $2.80 per dinner. And that’s using partially organic ingredients, in one of the most expensive cities in the world. How’s that for budget cooking?

item.title: budget bites: easy bean & cheese quesadillas
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
It's been quite a grueling week academically. Last minute debugging and lab reports means that I haven't slept earlier before 3 am in the past 3 days. This is a perfect busy week recipe: warm, cheesy, and ready in 5 minutes flat. Now, excuse me, as I should probably start my homework! Easy Bean & Cheese Quesadillas   Serves 1
  • 1 whole wheat tortilla
  • ¼ c refried beans
  • ¼ c shredded cheese
  1. On half of the tortilla, spread a thick layer of refried beans. Sprinkle with cheese and fold in half.
  2. Microwave on high for about 30 seconds, or until cheese melts and quesadilla is heated through.
  3. Cut into halves, and enjoy!
On another note, rest in peace, Steve Jobs. You were an inspiration to us all and a true genius.

item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: I got the funniest looking squash from the market the other day, isn't it such a bright & cheery color? I couldn't help but buy it. Turns out it's a hubbard squash. Cut it into hunks and roasted it slathered with olive oil and a smidge of salt and pepper. Not bad! It reminds me a bit of kabocha squash (my favorite!) in texture, but not as sweet. I absolutely adore all sorts of squash. Served with some artichoke ravioli from Trader Joe's (another thing I absolutely adore), it was a delicious dinner to celebrate the end of the week!

item.title: OMGrecipes: Dinglepopcakes!
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Last summer I interned at the online gaming company, OMGPOP. It was a great experience--when else do you get to play games on the job?? Not to mention the awesome co-workers! Today's recipe is inspired by one of my favorite games on the site: Dinglepop! They're mini homemade funfetti cupcakes decorated to look like the dingles. It's a lot simpler than it looks, and a great treat for any gamer friends you may have. Dinglepopcakes Tutorial Makes about 48 Supplies:
  • 1 batch of your favorite white cake recipe (you can use boxed cake mix--I'm just a from-scratch sort of girl :) )
  • 1 recipe your favorite vanilla frosting (again, a can of vanilla frosting will do the trick!)
  • red, blue, and yellow food coloring
  • 1/2 cup chocolate chips
  • a mini-muffin tin
  • mini-cupcake liners
Directions:
Mix up your cake batter according to the recipe or boxed directions. For fun, I threw in a handful of rainbow sprinkles, for instant funfetti!
Scoop into lined muffin cups, and bake for about 10-12 minutes at 350 degrees. Let them cool completely on wire racks. Meanwhile, make the frosting! Separate into five bowls, and stir in yellow food coloring into one, blue in another, and a combination of red + blue in the third until you get purple, and the same for green (blue + yellow) and orange (yellow + red). The toughest part of this whole project was getting the colors right--food coloring tends to look a bit muted once you stir it into frosting, and in the end my colors weren't exactly like those in the game, but don't worry, it will be tasty regardless! For simplicity's sake, I only made three colors of dingles, but since you're less of a slacker than I am, you should make all five :) Now, frost away! Once you're all done frosting (whew!) melt the chocolate chips in a small microwavable bowl in the microwave for about 30 -60 seconds, stirring until the chocolate's melted smooth. Now for the fun part: using a toothpick, draw two small lines on each cupcake for "eyes". Leave your cupcakes be and play a few games of Dinglepop so that the chocolate will harden and set. Feel free to arrange them into fun gameplays! OMGpop users: what game would you like to see next featured in OMGrecipes??

item.title: Hummus-coated Pasta with Crispy Sautéed Kale
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Sorry about the blog disappearance! Between vacation and packing and moving back in to school, not to mention internship applications and reunions with old friends, it’s been crazy busy around these parts. I promise to start posting regularly as soon as I get back into the swing of things.

Anyways, enough talk! Here’s a quick (took me only about 15 min from start to finish!), healthy, and comforting meal, perfect for the first day of classes in a brand new semester. Enjoy!

Hummus-coated Pasta with Crispy Sautéed Kale makes 2 servings (one for dinner, one for lunch tomorrow!)

  • about 2 cups of kale, chopped into bite-size pieces (I used about half a prewashed bag from my favorite grocery, Trader Joe’s!)
  • about 1 T olive oil
  • about 4oz whole wheat spaghetti (enough for 2 people)
  • ¼ cup hummus (I used original, but I bet flavored ones would be great! Sundried tomato, garlic, mmm....)
  • 2-3 tbs water
  • fresh lemon, optional
  1. Set a medium saucepan full of water over high heat. When the water boils, stir in the spaghetti.
  2. Meanwhile, heat a large nonstick pan over medium-high heat until very hot.
  3. Add oil, tilting to cover the bottom of the pan, then toss in kale, stirring quickly to coat and prevent from burning.
  4. Decrease heat to medium, stirring frequently, until kale starts to crisp and brown.
  5. If the kale is not cooking evenly, cover and let steam for a bit, giving it a stir every so often. Be careful not to let it burn--decrease heat if necessary!
  6. Sprinkle with salt & pepper and set aside.
  7. When pasta is ready, drain, and stir in the hummus, adding enough water to thin it out into a thick sauce.
  8. Sprinkle with salt and pepper, and add a healthy squeeze of lemon, if using.
  9. Serve warm or cold, topped with crispy kale!
Kale is one of my absolute favorite winter veggies--if you haven't tried it, you're missing out! Kale chips are another great way to enjoy them. All you busy bees out there: any other suggestions for quick & easy pasta meals?

item.title: #sorrynotsorry
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Man, it feels like forever since I've posted!

It's been, as always, crazy busy around these parts but today marks the advent of Spring Break (hallelujah!), a whole week to sleep and cook and eat (you can tell i've got my priorities straight), so there'll be new baking adventures soon, I promise!

Instead of attempting to come up with a coherent apology and description of what's been taking up my time, I figure I'd just say it the way I know best: in pictures!

Backstage at the Columbia Lunar Gala Fashion Show

Lion Dance and Wushu Performance at Lunar Gala

Me and my adorable friend Linda, who was one of the directors and has been dedicating endless hours of her time since last fall!

Midterms means...

Lots and lots of lattes! Above is a delicious concoction of whipped cream, cocoa, espresso, and a thick layer of melted chocolate from my favorite chain cafe, Aroma Espresso Bar

And a beautiful latte from Joe the Art of Coffee (fantastic coffee spot)

Some suprisingly yummy macro vegan sushi from the super market, my attempts to balance out all the stress-chocolate necessary to qualm exam nerves

And the most exciting and recent preoccupation: The Daily Beast's Women in the World Conference 2012!

I had the incredible opportunity as a Columbia student for a free theatre pass-- the event has been truly amazing and inspiring  so far (Hilary Clinton and Meryl Streep are speaking tomorrow!)

Speakers have included Sheryl Sandberg of Facebook, Jill Abramson (editor of the New York Times), Angelina Jolie, Nobel Laureate Leymah Gbowee, feminist Gloria Steinem, Nancy Pelosi, Madeleine Albright, and so many others...

All set in the classy David H Koch theatre!

It's been truly an honor to attend, and reminded me to be so incredibly grateful for what I have...but definitely also sadly aware of how often there still exists a glass ceiling (as Madeleine said, often a "thick wall of men") for women, especially in business and politics.

Also: on a side note, I've been working on designing my personal site, check it out!

item.title: adventures in cake pops
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Rainbow sprinkles make the world go round

Here's an incredibly belated pictorial post on my adventures making cake pops (well more like little spherical cupcakes, not the usual mashed cake-and-frosting kind) with the lovely Melissa when I visited her home in Miami! Sweet memories of a warmer place :)

The little cake-pop molds

Whipping up cake batter (funfetti, of course!)

Mel the baker

Some of them overexpanded! We ate those pieces off, no biggie :)

Some of them stuck too the pan...glued those back together with chocolate!

Then it was off to the fridge to let the chocolate-dipped sticks set

We dipped them in chocolate ganache made by Mel's talented little sister Ashley, who is quite the chef at 12!

Cake makes me smile!

We made pretty gold-flaked cupcakes with the remaining batter and ganache!

item.title: thanksgiving weekend 2011
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
It's been quite a hellish week for me at school... But here are Thanksgiving photos, finally! Thanksgiving is one of my favorite holidays. Not only does it mark the beginning of the holiday season, it comes at a usually stressful time in the semester where taking a weekend off and putting it all in perspective  with the ones I love most is much needed. And did I mention the food? This was our fancy menu, planned out by my Aunt Joy, who every year hosts our holiday dinner and comes up with a delicious and creative theme! This year, we went all-out Italian. The results were impressive, considering that none of us are the slightest bit Italian nor have had any experience with the cuisine! First up: For lunch, a delicious Cioppino ( a hearty seafood stew full of shrimp, mussels, clam, crab, and scallops!) with homemade bread spiced with rosemary (courtesy of Uncle Ken).

After filling ourselves to the brim with seafood, it was time to start cooking for the main event--Thanksgiving dinner!

This year, instead of the traditional turkey, we decided to throw a curveball by making roast pork instead--slow roasted in a dutch oven all day until the meat was tender and delicious.   Here's a glass of sparkling pomegranate juice, which was a lovely and light non-alcoholic alternative. A light salad of arugula, raddichio, and romaine with aged balsamic dressing One of my favorites: roasted root vegetables with thyme and oregano! I absolutely adore roasted veggies, and this combination of parsnips, rutabaga, turnips, and sweet potato was superb. (I'm still enjoying the leftovers at school!) Peas studded with bits of fried pancetta and pine nuts was a sweet-and-salty delight. Here's the roast pork, carved for the dinner table. It was so tender that it fell apart at the touch! The set table My dinner plate (well, the first plate, anyway) And just when you thought it couldn't get any better, dessert time! My aunt and uncle made an impressive "Crostata di Mele con Frangipane"--apple tart with homemade frangipane! It was so beautiful and rich. We topped it off with vanilla gelato! After that...a nap! It was so much fun to prepare and eat such an elaborate feast. Something about being away at college and living on my own definitely makes me appreciate a nice warm homemade meal that much more.

item.title: stressed is desserts spelled backwards
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Don't get me wrong, I love my alma mater-to-be, but sometimes, being at the nation's number one stressed school has its downsides.

Like staying up all night on the weekends...studying. (Once, there was a fire drill in the library, and the firemen asked us what the hell all these kids were doing there on a Friday night.)

Like that time class was cancelled...and people stayed on anyway, to participate in "intellectual discussion".

Like that genius kid who ruins the curve in calculus by getting a 100 on every test.

Like when you have 2 projects and a lab due during finals week, with 4 finals to go. (Now. Sorry I've been MIA on the blog.)

Good thing a wise man once (should have) said, when life gives you stress, make cookies!

Peanut butter cookies.

Two kinds.

Peanut Butter Chocolate Chip Oatmeal Cookies

Makes 1 dozen adapted from Handle the Heat
With whole wheat flour, oatmeal, and peanut butter, these are cookies are wholesome yet seriously addictive!
They have great texture: crispy outside, soft melty inside, full of chocolate chips & pb.
  • ½ c pb
  • ½ c brown sugar
  • 1 large egg
  • ¼ c whole wheat flour
  • ¼ c oatmeal
  • ¼ t cinnamon
  • ½ t baking soda
  • ¼ c chocolate chips
  1. Preheat oven to 350F and grease a baking sheet.
  2. In a large bowl, mix pb and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in egg.
  3. Stir in flour, then mix in oats, baking soda, and cinnamon. Fold in chocolate chips. Don’t overmix!
  4. Scoop out tablespoons of dough, place on baking sheet, and flatten slightly.
  5. Bake for 10-12 min, or until tops are lightly golden.
  6. Cool on a wire rack. Cookies may be stored in an airtight container for 3-4 days...if they last!

Peanut Butter-Nutella Thumbprints Makes about 15 cookies Adapted from That’s So Vegan
Nutella and peanut butter: one dream team. These cookies are sooo good, with a melt-in-mouth honey-scented dough and rich filling. I made them for my school newspaper's Secret Santa and they were quite well received!
  • 1 c AP flour
  • ½ t baking soda
  • ½ t salt
  • ½ c pb
  • ½ c honey
  • ⅙ c oil
  • 1 t vanilla
  • Nutella for filling (about ½ c)
  1. Preheat oven to 350F and line 2 cookie sheets.
  2. In a medium bowl, mix flour, baking soda, and salt.
  3. In a large bowl, stir together pb, honey, oil, and vanilla until creamy. Stir in dry ingredients until combined.
  4. Roll tbs of dough into balls and place on baking sheets.
  5. Bake for about 8-10 min, or until lightly browned.
  6. Make indents with thumb, and fill with Nutella!
  7. Cool completely before serving.

item.title: five facts for friday
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: what has Mon Petit Chou been up to lately? 1. Fashion Friday is dead (long live Fashion Friday!). Thanks to slow suffocation by finals and cold weather, my semester-long weekly fashion posts are now at an end. Will this be forever? Likely not, as eventually I will have to stop wearing glasses and messy buns and put on some pants. However, the weekly format has been, for now, put off. 2. Petit Doodles! Check out the right sidebar for little doodles done by me. Most of them may or may not have been drawn during Data Structures and Physics Lab on my iPhone. 3. I've been working on a simple Django web app for the past few days. By working I mean hacking, armed with Google and my very limited knowledge of web development, trying to make deadlines so I can be employed for the summer. 4. Latest obsession: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo! Before I left for home I saw the American movie with some college buddies, and now I'm desperately trying to get my hands on a copy of the book (the library's all out!). It was a tad (by tad I mean 1000 times) more violent/scary than my usual taste, but I'm in love with Lisbeth Salander. Does anyone else feel the same way? I mean, come on, she's all sorts of lesbian/anti-authoritarian/feminist/hacker awesome. Like all my favorite things, and badass too. And there was a cat in the movie! Except the cat died. And Lisbeth gets raped. And yeah, lots of bad stuff happens. 5. Sophie is reunited with Nummy. See photo above. Nummy may or may not like this.

item.title: sweet potato fudge brownies
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Happy New Year! I can hardly believe it's already 2012--12 whole years since the new millenium. I feel so old saying this, but there are times where I still think that 2000 sounds futuristic, and then I remember it's been more than a decade... With the new year comes the perfect opportunity to reflect on one's life, and perhaps make some changes. (I've been procrastinating as usual and still haven't made up my resolutions yet...hmm...maybe that would make a good resolution...) Here's a lightened up fudge brownie recipe adapted from Martha Stewart (via Neverhomemaker) in honor of the New Year. It's made with sweet potatoes and vegan to boot but tastes totally decadent (so extremely chocolatey and FUDGY)! Perfect for those get-healthy resolutions... Sweet Potato Fudge Brownies adapted from neverhomemaker 4 tablespoons canola oil 2/3 cup unsweetened cocoa powder 1/2 cup all purpose flour (whole wheat pastry flour would be great, and healthier too!) 1/4 teaspoon baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 2/3 cup organic cane sugar 2/3 cup sweet-potato puree 1 flax egg (see directions below) 1 teaspoon vanilla extract 1/2 cup chocolate chips
  1. Preheat your oven to 350 degrees F, and grease an 8" baking pan.
  2. In a small microwave-safe bowl, whisk together 1 tablespoon golden flax meal with three tablespoons water. Then heat on high for 30 seconds. Stir and set aside to cool.
  3. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, and salt. Set aside.
  4. In another bowl, combine the sweet potato puree with the oil, flax egg, vanilla, and sugar. Mix until smooth.
  5. Add the wet ingredients to the dry. Mix until everything is well moistened and stir in the chocolate chips. (The dough will be a bit stiff and extremely fudgy!)
  6. Spread into your prepared pan and bake for about 20 min, or until just set. (These brownies are extremely fudgy so a toothpick won't likely come out clean.)
  7. Enjoy warm and gooey, or let cool a bit for easier slicing :)
                      So fudgy and chocolatey...

item.title: sweet review: bouchon bakery, columbus circle
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: Living in New York is an absolute dream for a pastry aficionado like myself (among many other reasons!). There seems to be a new hot bakery springing up somewhere in Manhattan every week--an endless stream of cupcakes and ice cream and doughnuts and gelato to try. Not that I'm complaining, at all! Last weekend my sister was in the city for the day, so we decided to scope out the Bouchon Bakery in the 3rd floor of the swanky Times Warner Center at Columbus Circle. Founded by the famous chef Thomas Keller, the chain of Bouchon Bakeries have drawn quite positive reviews so of course I had to try it for myself. Here's our spread, which we enjoyed in Central Park, since (like everything else in New York!) there was very little sitting room next to the bakery storefront. First off, a cute little chocolate tart. I have to say the presentation at Bouchon was quite lovely, as you can see with the little gold leaf and delicate placement of hazelnuts. But did the taste live up to its beautiful presentation? Unfortunately, the tart was good, but not fantastic-- the embedding of too-crunchy/hard whole cocoa nibs in the otherwise smooth filling and odd strands of sugar in the crust did not lead to such a pleasing taste experience. Simpler, and better chocolate tarts to be had elsewhere. Having had pastries at the Laduree on les Champs-Elysees, I feel qualified to review any macaron that comes my way. These were very good for an American bakery--rather large (the size of one's palm!) but sufficiently moist, with good structure and a nice twist with the cranberry flavor and smooth filling. Always a sucker for "fun foods", I couldn't help but give the chocolate "Ho-Ho" a go, an upscale rendition of the Hostess snack-cake. It was good, but again, not mind blowing, chocolate sponge rolled up with chocolate mousse inside, enrobed in a layer of more chocolate. Of course, being the caffeine addict that I am, I had a cup of coffee to wash it all down. The coffee was quite good, for a bakery. Overall, it was a pleasant sugar high for a Saturday afternoon. However, given the higher prices and lack of seating room/over-hype (like every other thing in the City!), I would prefer to take my afternoon coffee break in a cozier cafe, as the desserts were delicious, but nothing mind-blowing. Still, definitely worth trying! If you go: Bouchon Bakery, Times Warner Center Ten Columbus Circle, Third Floor New York, NY 10019 212.823.9366 www.bouchonbakery.com

item.title: Merry Christmas Eve eve!
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
I can hardly believe it's only two days until Christmas! With the stress of exams and school making the days a caffeinated blur, and the unusually sadly warm weather, it hardly seems like late December.

Holidays are not big deals at our house, but still, there's something exciting about all the anticipation. And of course, it's an excuse to bake dozens and dozens of cookies!

Aren't these reindeer cookies just adorable? I used the same peanut butter cookie recipe as for the Peanut Butter Nutella Thumbprints, and it turned out great!

Little Reindeer Cookies Makes about 15 cookies

  • 1 c AP flour
  • ½ t baking soda
  • ½ t salt
  • ½ c pb
  • ½ c honey
  • ⅙ c oil
  • 1 t vanilla
  • 1 bag mini pretzel twists, broken into halves
  • 1 bag m&ms
  • mini chocolate chips
  1. Preheat oven to 350F and line 2 cookie sheets.
  2. In a medium bowl, mix flour, baking soda, and salt.
  3. In a large bowl, stir together pb, honey, oil, and vanilla until creamy. Stir in dry ingredients until combined.
  4. Roll tbs of dough into balls and place on baking sheets.
  5. Stick two pretzel halves into each dough ball for “antlers”.
  6. Bake for approximately 10 min, and immediately press an m&m into the center of each cookie for the nose, and 2 mini chocolate chips for eyes.
  7. Cool completely before serving!
Happy Holidays from Mon Petit Chou! P.S. Now that I'm on break, home and full of mom's cooking, expect more posts coming up :)

item.title: as easy as pb&j
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Homemade gifts are always a welcome respite from the usual mass commercialization of the holiday season. Plus, more the motivation to experiment in the kitchen! I'm almost embarrassed to post this recipe on my blog because it's just SO simple. It's a great gift for any Nutella or Reeses' fanatic (and who isn't? I happen to be both). I gave it to my dear friend in a Secret Santa exchange and she really enjoyed it!   Super Simple Peanutella Recipe from the Family Kitchen STEP ONE: Mix equal amounts no-stir, creamy peanut butter and chocolate chips in a microwavable bowl.
STEP TWO: Microwave on High for about a minute, or until pb is melted. STEP THREE: Stir until chocolate is fully incorporated with the peanut butter (the heat of the pb will cause it to melt!) and spread is smooth and glossy. STEP FOUR: Pour into jar(s), and let set at room temperature until firm! STEP FIVE: Don't let your family and friends know just how easy it was to make ;)

item.title: making banana pancakes...
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Nothing smells spells weekend like pancakes! Unlike this recipe for single-serving Pumpkin Chocolate Chip Pancakes, (which are fluffy and delicious and pumpkin-y and chocolate-y but also makes a wee bit too much pancake for one petite person), these Choco-Banana recipe makes just 2 pancakes: perfect for a sweet breakfast treat: no more, no less. Choco-Banana Pancakes for One Serves 1! (Makes 2 pancakes)
  • ¼ c whole wheat flour
  • ½ t baking powder
  • ½ T sugar
  • a dash of cinnamon
  • a pinch of salt
  • ¼ c soy or almond milk
  • ½ t canola oil
  • a handful of chocolate chips
  • 1/2 banana, sliced
  1. Lightly grease a skillet and preheat over medium heat.
  2. Meanwhile, stir together all dry ingredients in a bowl, and all the wet in another. Add the wet into the dry and stir just to combine. Stir in chocolate chips.
  3. Ladle about ¼ cups of batter onto preheated skillet and top each pancake with a few slices of banana. Cook for 2-3 min. or until bubbles form along the top and edges are firm. Flip and cook for another 2-3 min.
  4. Serve warm.

item.title: a fancy schmancy meal
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: Oh Trader Joe's, how I love you. I love you even when your line wraps all the way around to the milk aisle and you make my weekly grocery bill double. How could I not be inspired to whip up something special? Lemon Pepper Mahi Mahi with Balsamic Baby Zucchini & Whole Wheat Couscous This was an ad-lib sort of meal that went something like this: 1. Get thee a bag of adorable little baby zucchini. Try not to feel too bad about eating them all about. 2. Slice them in half lengthwise (ignore the screaming). Sautee with olive oil, a good sprinkling of salt & pepper, & douse with Lemon Pepper Mrs. Dash seasoning. When nice and browned, drizzle on some good balsamic vinegar and cook until reduced. (I might omit the vinegar next time: it was yummy but the flavor of the zucchini was so delicate some of it was overwhelmed.) 3. Meanwhile, defrost your frozen Mahi Mahi steaks under cold running water. 4. When it is all nice and defrosted open up the package and curse the manufacturing for putting the cooking instructions inside the wrapping so you had to google "how to cook frozen mahi mahi" for 15 minutes. 5. Sautee for about 3 min a side in a pan drizzled with olive oil, and sprinkled with salt, pepper, and once again, lemon pepper seasoning (poor man's lemons?), until fish is opaque but not dry. 6. Win friends and influence people OR shut door and enjoy all to yourself. (I choose the latter.) (Sorry for the lack of real recipe: just be creative and it will be delicious, I promise! Voila the magic of Trader Joe's.)

item.title: portobello cheeseburgers
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
I love mushrooms and have been meaning for the longest time to try my hand at making Portobello burgers! The results, as suspected, were fantastic--the mushrooms are meaty and juicy and full of flavor from the marinade, a great contrast to the melty cheese. Portobello Cheese Burgers adapted from All Recipes makes 4 burgers
  • 4 portobello mushroom caps
  • 1/4 cup balsamic vinegar
  • 2 tablespoons olive oil
  • 1 teaspoon dried basil
  • 1 teaspoon dried oregano
  • 1 tablespoon minced garlic
  • salt and pepper to taste
  • 4 (1 ounce) slices pepper jack or other semi-soft cheese
  • 4 whole wheat hamburger buns
  1. Place the mushroom caps, smooth side up, in a shallow dish. In a small bowl, whisk together vinegar, oil, basil, oregano, garlic, salt, and pepper. Pour over the mushrooms. Let stand at room temperature for 15 minutes or so, turning twice.
  2. Preheat a large saucepan on medium-high heat. (Alternatively, you can grill burgers for a more traditional taste!)
  3. Place mushrooms on the pan, reserving marinade for basting.
  4. Grill uncovered for 5 to 8 minutes on each side, or until tender and sauce is reduced, frequently basting by spooning over leftover marinade.
  5. Meanwhile, lightly toast the hamburger buns.
  6. As soon as portobellos are ready, quickly top with a slice of cheese, and sandwich with desired toppings in hamburger bun.
  7. Enjoy warm!

item.title: Smashing Sardine Pasta
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Some days should come with a caution label-- warning: need for extra caffeine. Today was one of those days: problem sets and coding until 5:30 am, work from 10-1, class from 1-6, scrambling to finish homework in lecture. Days like this, food is no small comfort: a warm and hearty dinner can make all the difference in the world! Enter this speedy pasta dish, made up on the fly with leftovers in the fridge and an oft-overlooked (but incredibly nourishing) pantry staple: sardines. Perfect brain food to get you through even the busiest of days! Smashing Sardine Pasta Serves 1 (although it's always handy to double up on pasta for lunch the next day!)
  • 1 can sardines in tomato sauce (about 3-4 oz)
  • 2 oz whole wheat spaghetti
  • 2 c fresh spinach
  • 1 T olive oil
  • 1 T fresh lemon juice (1/2 lemon)
  • generous amount of fresh ground pepper!
  1. In a small pot, bring water to a rolling boil. Cook spaghetti according to box directions until al dente. Drain and coat with olive oil.
  2. In the same pot, steam spinach with a bit of water until soft and wilted. Toss with spaghetti, and drizzle with ample lemon juice and fresh black pepper (be generous here--it really brightens up the dish!).
  3. Top with sardines and sauce.
  4. Enjoy!
Thank goodness it's Thursday! College can be like bootcamp sometimes, but I'll be forever grateful for 3-day weekends.

item.title: tasting the menu at Corton NYC
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Recently I had the pleasure of joining my lovely roommate and her boyfriend for dinner at Corton NYC in TriBeCa. I'm not going to write a comprehensive review of the tasting menu we enjoyed because, quite frankly, I've never had a dining experience on such an elaborate scale before. Although the cuisine was deemed Nouveau French, there was a definite Eastern influence and it seemed more like Asian fusion. There were 10+ courses in all, and each bite (in order to not overwhelm the stomach, most courses were 1-2 bite creations) was truly a "taste"--really intensified flavor in a small package. Some combinations worked better than others, but all in all, it was an undeniably creative and fun feast.

Big thanks (and a safe trip home!) to Max!

the menu

delicious assortment of mini breads: baguette, caramelized onion foccacia with seaweed & sweet cream butters

amuse-bouches

mini cheese puff

coddled parmesan egg

beautiful presentation all around!

raddichio with berry sorbet

meringues were everywhere: here, in stick form

mini braised radish

tiny little sweetbread burger served on a huge slab of salt

gnocchi and octopus

apple, lime & wasabi palate-cleanser

the swordfish entree

squab entree

I don't remember what this was, but it was pretty

cheese course: conte and white chocolate

meringue makes a comeback, in a citrusy sorbet dessert

chocolate olive oil mousse

And the icing on the cake (my favorite course!): the final dessert

(black olive and berry macarons, assorted chocolate truffles--rosemary, olive oil, and salted caramel!)

item.title: a weekend in Providence...Rhode Island
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
My childhood friend & cousin Alice is graduating from Brown University at the end of next month...It is sometimes frightening how fast time passes, seems like just yesterday we were playing Super Smash Bros. in her living room (then again, we may have done that last year). I spent the weekend in Providence, to make sure I would visit her Alma Mater at least once before she left! Providence is quite a pretty little town and although not New York has some quality food! First up: Kabob & Curry There aren't many decent Indian restaurants that I know of in Morningside Heights, so this was the perfect opportunity to indulge!  

And indulge we did...

we ordered crispy fried Vegetable Samosas and paper-thin Papadum to start, with a plethora of dipping sauces & chutneys, then for entrees, the famous Chicken Tikki Marsala and Palak Paneer (my favorite!) with plenty of fresh Naan.

to wash it all down: thick Mango Lassi!

And all of this came up to a mere $22 per person, with tip and tax. Sweet!

The next morning we stumbled down to Louis Restaurant around noon for a late breakfast/brunch. Truly a mom-&-pop dive-y place, this little diner was featured on the Food Network show Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives (check out the clip!).

Since the place is quite small, we had to wait a bit for our table. Outside, they were selling baskets of fresh fruit (bananas and mangoes) for $1. Yum!

Their fruit cup is truly the most pretty fruit cup I have ever encountered.

I ordered the Granola Pancakes (as featured in Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives!) topped with fresh fruit, and a nice milky glass of iced coffee. When I saw the fruit cup, I was worried that fruit-topped pancakes could not live up to it. Thankfully, my fears were unnecessary! These had to be the most gloriously fruit-topped pancakes I had ever seen. No watery frozen-thawed wimpy blueberries for Louis!

All around the diner, the walls were decorated with the most interesting photos, fan letters, and tchotchkes.

item.title: The Halfway Mark
item.dc:creator: sophie

item.title: toasted coconut chocolate chip cookies
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Hello, Cookie. You are very delicious indeed, albeit a tad unphotogenic. Sweet. Sassy. And a little bit nutty. Coco-nutty, that is.

This is the first time I've ever put coconut in cookies, but it will most definitely not be the last! These cookies par excellence: crispy on the outside, sweet & chewy on the inside, and full of chocolate. I was in a rush but I was still able to get them made from start to finish in 30 minutes. The original recipe called for chocolate chunks but I only had mini chips which resulted in a smattering of chocolate in every bite!

Bonus: since the original recipe was from Cooking Light, you only need a bit (4 tablespoons) of butter!

 Toasted Coconut Chocolate Chip Cookies

Makes 18 cookies (original yield 15, but I got 18 nice-sized cookies!)

Adapted from Two Peas and their Pod (changes in parentheses)

  • 1 cup flaked sweetened coconut (unsweetened organic flaked coconut)
  • 1 cup all purpose flour
  • 1/2 teaspoon baking powder
  • 1/4 teaspoon baking soda
  • 1/8 teaspoon salt
  • 3/4 cup packed light brown sugar
  • 4 tablespoons unsalted butter, at room temperature
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • 1/4 teaspoon coconut extract (omitted)
  • 1 large egg (extra large)
  • 3/4 cup chopped semi-sweet or bittersweet chocolate (mini chocolate chips)
  1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
  2. Toast coconut: arrange coconut in a single layer on baking sheet. Bake for 5-7 minutes or until coconut is lightly toasted, stirring once. Be very careful as it will burn rapidly! Set coconut aside to cool.
  3. Lightly grease or line another baking sheet and set aside.
  4. Whisk together flour, baking powder, soda, and salt in a medium bowl.
  5. In a large bowl, add brown sugar and butter. Beat until creamy and smooth. (Originally called for stand mixer, but a fork and lots of elbow grease does the job!)
  6. Beat in vanilla and egg. Slowly stir in flour mixture, and mix just until combined.
  7. Stir in toasted coconut and chocolate chunks.
  8. Drop spoonfuls of dough 2 inches apart onto prepared baking sheet. Bake at 350° for 10 minutes or until bottoms of cookies just begin to brown. Remove from pan, and cool completely on wire racks.

item.title: banana ginger chocolate chip softies
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Ah, home sweet home! After a grueling exams week, I'm finally back in Jersey. Well, for a week at least--I move in to start my summer fellowship program Sunday (more on that later). Of course I put no time to waste in indulging in all the best things about break: banana chocolate-chip pancakes for breakfast, slurping down my favorite banana-cocoa smoothies twice a day, taking the scissors to the closet, lovingly harassing the cat, taking 3-hour naps, and watching many re-runs of that 70's show. And, naturally, baking cookies! I adore candied ginger and these cookies were inspired by my addiction to the spicy sweet taste. I used mini chocolate chips for more uniform chocolate per bite (it's all about the math, folks). Because they don't contain any added fat or egg, these cookies end up being very, very moist, which is a great thing taste-wise, but not so great if you want to transport or store them for too long. So eat 'em while they're warm and spicy, with a friend or two to share with!

Ginger Chocolate-Chip Banana Softies Makes about 16 cookies Adapted from VegWeb

1 ¼ c whole wheat flour ½ t baking soda ½ t salt 1 very ripe banana ½ c unsweetened applesauce (1 snack-pack) ½ c sugar 1 t vanilla ½ c crystallized ginger, chopped ⅓ c mini chocolate chips

  1. Preheat oven to 350F and line two baking sheets with parchment paper.
  2. In a medium bowl, mix flour, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.
  3. In a large bowl, mash banana. Stir in applesauce, sugar, and vanilla. Gradually stir in dry mixture, mixing well after each addition, until smooth. Fold in ginger and chocolate chips.
  4. Drop heaping tablespoons of batter 2” apart on prepared pans.
  5. Bake for 12-15 min, or until slightly browned and firm to touch.
  6. Cool completely on wire racks before attempting to remove from parchment or transport. They are very soft!
Notes:
  • The original recipe called for baking powder too, but I totally forgot to add it! Maybe it would have turned out a bit puffier?

item.title: sweet summertime
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Long time no blog, I know, I'm sorry. It seems like the last load of laundry from school was scarce dry before I was packing up my bags once again and trucking my suitcases back and self back to the City--this time, in the heart of things, right next to Union Square. This lucky piece of prime real estate was landed for the summer with no small thanks to a great fellowship organization that I am proud to call myself a member of. hackNY, which is now in its 3rd year, seeks to foster a community of young "hackers" and entrepreneurs by providing sponsored housing and a full-time internship at a start-up in New York City to top students/hackers around the nation. Although it is a fun and exciting opportunity, it also leaves little time for baking and blogging! Here's my best effort to makeup for lost blogging time by a quick photo recap:

a little friend on the windowsill

a beautiful day at Riverside Park 

(although it's been raining now for a week straight!)

did you know there's free kayaking on the Hudson?! Yes yes.

Super rich mac & cheese from Giorgio's of Gramercy 

(but not fiscally thanks to Groupon!)

The most fudgy, chocolatey Smores' Bread Pudding! 

The little balls are chocolate spots!

Thank goodness it's Friday tomorrow! Forty-hour workweeks are quite a physical strain after the more fluid schedule of university life. Happy upcoming Memorial Day weekend!

Nota Bene: I've been ruminating for a while now about starting another (more serious) blog for musings and opinions. I have a feeling that mixing food and politics and/or social critiques may lead to a bad appetite for all involved, so it would be a separate entity. Thoughts/suggestions?

item.title: shake shake shake
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: Yesterday my dear friend Lyndsey came to visit and we had quite a delicious day! We are both big fans of art and so we spent the whole afternoon exploring the MOMA. We managed to go through every room on every floor, in just a bit more than 2 hours! After that we made a beeline for Shake Shack, New York's most popular burger and shake chain. Unfortunately, it's also a tourist favorite, and so the line for burgers was ridiculously long. We settled for sweets instead, since the line for cold food was much shorter. This is a "Concrete", which according to Shake Shack's menu is "Dense frozen custard blended at high speed with toppings & mix-ins". I got the Shack Attack® :Chocolate custard, fudge sauce, chocolate truffle cookie dough and Mast Brothers Shake Shack blend chocolate, topped with chocolate sprinkles. Lyndsey got good ol' plain chocolate, a familiar favorite. We both thought it was more like soft ice cream than a shake. In fact, I couldn't really tell what made it a "concrete". Of course, ice cream is always welcome on a hot, muggy day, but maybe I would just go for the cheaper alternative next time. Thank goodness Madison Square Eats (a mini food stand fest) was going on across the street! All the food looked amazing, and I choose to try the vegetarian Mel + Steve (asian sesame slaw on top of veggie dog) from AsiaDog, an Asian Fusion hot dog stand. Lyndsey and I both agreed it was by far the prettiest hot dog (with the purple cabbage slaw) that we'd ever seen! And the taste was great, too :) Note: Later that night I actually went to Shake Shack AGAIN, for a hackNY team-building event, and got to try the famous 'Shroom Burger (deep fried portabello stuffed with Muenster), with cheese fries on the side. They were to die for! I don't see anything great in the shakes, but the hot food at Shake Shack is greasy goodness. This is how I felt after feasting all day:

item.title: Eating Week
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
This week has left me, in a word, very, very, full

. And also, very, very excited to spend my Friday night in bed with the Netflix.

This week, there was...

a lot of ice cream consumed. Goddammit, when the mercury rises New York becomes a veritable Sophie-trap with ice cream trucks on every corner. I have never been able to resist a good cone on the way home from work, and since this is Manhattan, we're not talking about the good stuff, not just Mr. Softee (although that always hits the spot!). This particular delightful specimen is from Amornino Gelato, near Union Square. It's Dark Chocolate, Tiramisu, and Hazelnut. Isn't she a beaut?

an overload of cuteness at the office. I swear to God, the company I work at could win some sort of cute dog competition. This here is Squishy the pug, and she lives up to her name indeed.

many a bear at Bare Burger a delicious organic burger mini-chain in NYC. (But no actual bears harmed in the noshing.)

I opted for the veggie option and was NOT disappointed--BareBurger makes a mean meatless patty topped with lots of melty cheese, creamy avocado (my fave!), all on a sturdy multigrain bun.

It's called the California, and it was sunny indeed.

I couldn't resist trying one of their organic sodas on the menu, and the Blueberry Soda was the perfect touch to a delicious meal.

Both wontons and ramen in my soup for dinner. Can't make up your mind? Then go for the Shrimp Wonton Noodle Soup at Noodle Village, in Chinatown. One note: it is a bit on the blander side, (although it's a good sign if you're tired of over-salty, MSG-laden packaged ramen).

And finally, another cute pup to close out the day, this one I spotted on the floor of a hair salon in C-town. She even had little barrettes in her fur!

item.title: Orange you cute?
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: As a fun & cheery touch for our latest Nom^3 bakesale, I hand-decorated 70+ mini clementines with foodsafe markers. I have to say, it was a quite an entertaining to procrastinate on a Sunday night! Somewhere around the 20th clementine, I decided to get a little creative and deviate from the usual smiley. The resulting creations follow.

item.title: pork katsu bento box
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
$9, from m2m, the neighborhood "asian" grocery store

a bit pricey, but plenty of food for dinner today and lunch tomorrow!

Contents: sticky white rice, pork katsu cutlet, rolled omelette,

coleslaw, cherry tomato, mashed potatoes, pickles, katsu sauce

I just love bento boxes!

item.title: a french connection
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: I am something of a thrift store addict. I got hooked last summer working next door to the Housing Works thrift shop in Soho and the magnificent used bookstore/cafe next door (I am a used books fiend. My paycheck suffered.). I don't think I've ever walked into Housing Works without walking out with a new pair of shoes, but, hey, all for a good cause, right? Walking down to Trader Joe's on a sunny day can turn dangerous as I am always tempted to stop at all the shops along the way, and last weekend was no exception. One of the best things about used clothing is the stories that are left behind with them. I got this adorable French Connection skirt for a mere $20, and just today, as I was reaching into the pocket, out comes two ticket stubs: one to the Fondation C. Monet, and another to the Musee Impressionnismes. French Connection, vraiment!

item.title: Everybody Likes Sandwiches
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: Long time no blog, I know, I know. The truth is I've been beyond mad busy with work, and enjoying summertime in the city. But the real excuse is that a full time job + tutoring on the side + fast food too often + not enough rest = not the best appetite. And if you know anything about me, it's that I can never say no to doing something fun or good food. Unfortunately, that's wreaking havoc on my health. I'm trying to take things a bit easier and hopefully the food adventures will restart. On a less depressing note, I've been trying to amp-up the home-cooking (eating out every meal just can't be good!) and here's one tasty result: Sauteed zucchini + Sabra hummus on a fresh, delicious, seed-y roll from Whole Foods. New best homemade sandwich ever! I really am a firm believer in the school of thought that the bread makes the sandwich, and this roll was superb!

item.title: chocolate & caffeine
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
that's my motto for finals week!

5 exams in 7 days, it's gonna be a tough one.

Thank goodness for...

lovingly made lattes in Joe's,

and chocolate from Trader Joe's!

This is a dark chocolate candy bar filled with Speculoos, a gingerbread cookie spread (that some say is the new Nutella!)

I've actually never had Speculoos by itself before, only drizzled on waffles from the Wafels and Dinges truck.

This was a delicious composition!

But can anything ever replace Nutella in the heart of a chocolate fiend?

item.title: chocolate banana swirl muffins
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Here's a fun and delicious alternative to a sweet breakfast staple: banana bread with a (chocolate) twist! To make Monday mornings a bit brighter, I also used a cute heart shaped tin to bake the muffins in, although a regular cupcake tin or large loaf pan will work just fine. This recipe is very moist, thanks to the applesauce and plentiful bananas (it contains no added fat or eggs!). The cocoa cake is full of chocolate flavor and makes a delicious and pretty contrast to the bananas. Chocolate Swirl Banana Bread Muffins (Vegan) Makes 1 dozen Adapted from Passion4Eating
  • 4 very ripe bananas
  • 1 snack-pack unsweetened applesauce (1/3 c)
  • ½ c brown sugar
  • 2 t vanilla
  • 1 ½ c AP flour
  • 1 t baking soda
  • a pinch of salt
  • ⅓ c cocoa powder
  1. Preheat oven to 350F and line a muffin tin.
  2. In a large bowl, mash bananas, applesauce, brown sugar, and vanilla.
  3. Sift in flour, baking soda, and salt. Stir until smooth.
  4. Scoop out ½ the batter into another bowl and mix in the cocoa powder.
  5. In each muffin cup, alternate a scoop of banana batter with chocolate batter. Lightly swirl with a knife (don’t overdo it!).
  6. Bake for about 20 min, or until a toothpick comes clean.

item.title: mini chip whoopie pies with strawberry buttercream
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
It was so sunny and mild outside I thought a little berry flavor was due :)

Fluffy disks of vanilla cake...

Bright strawberry filling!

Viva la spring break.

(No recipe, as the one I used turned out to be a bit of a flop,

and resulted in a lot of adjustments mid-baking.)

item.title: Fun with Glasses
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Thank God for Tina Fey. She has, among other things, (such as being hilarious!) made the once-nerdy glasses "nerdy-chic". Still, whenever I'm bespectacled, I can't help but remember the old idiotic adage: "Girls with glasses don't get passes", which makes me want to punch myself twice, once for being superficial, and another time for being a bad feminist. Anyways, I had a ball picking out these fun glasses at Zenni Optical, where they were having a great "Buy 2 get 1 free" sort of deal. The total was only around $50 for 3 glasses which is a very, very good price. Overall I was quite pleased with my order although it was a bit slow--the quality is not bad for plastic frames, and the prescription feels good. The only thing is that their factories are located in China so that may lead to further ethical investigations especially since their prices are so low, but we will save that for another discussion.

Round Frames

Nerdy Aviators (for Hackathons, 3-am coding sessions, etc.)

Retro Cat-Eyed

Side note: I am proud to say these are the product of nerd power and hope to fuel some more nerdy projects (as anyone who is a Computer Scientist knows, programming with contacts in is a very bad idea)! The money I used to buy them was taken from a prize I won at the Columbia University DevFest in the first week of January (well, the prize was a Kindle but I prefer my books on paper so I sold that on Craigslist).

item.title: hoppy easter!
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
I first spied this adorable concept of a cupcake in, of course, Martha Stewart magazine. (Although, now that I look at it, my chicks turned out a bit different in style, but no less cute, n'est-ce pas? Martha seemed to have iced the cupcake upside down for a nice tapered shape, that clever bastard.) Anyhoo, this proved to be quite a fun & uplifting Sunday afternoon project. Here's a rough sketch/recipe: Baby Chick Cupcakes Makes 12 Adapted from Martha Stewart Living Ingredients:
  • 1 recipe for 1 dozen of your favorite vanilla cupcakes (you can use cake mix, too!)
  • 1 can vanilla frosting (I used the "whipped" kind to make it nice and fluffy)
  • about 1/2 bag coconut, unsweetened
  • mini chocolate chips (24)
  • toasted whole almonds (36)
  1. Prepare cupcakes and bake according to instructions. Let cool completely.
  2. Meanwhile, toast the coconut: spread into a baking sheet and bake at 350F for about 10 min, stirring constantly. Be careful not to let it burn. Let cool completely.
  3. When everything's nice and cooled, it's time to assemble the chicks!
  4. Frost the bottom and sides of each cupcake and coat thoroughly/roll in coconut. (Note: I actually messed up and frosted the top and sides, hence my slightly squashed-looking chicks. Still yummy, though!)
  5. For each chick, stick on 2 chocolate chips and an almond for the beak. Push two almond into the bottom for feet.
  6. Repeat until you have a nice little coop of chickies :)
  7. Eat, if you can bring yourself to do it!
                      This little fella in the center has a different artistic director, but the design was veto-ed in favor of the upright chicks.

item.title: 3.14159...it's what's for dessert!
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded:
Chocolate Peanut Butter Mousse Pie. Oh my goodness. So rich. So good. And so easy! Did I mention it's no-bake? And vegan!

Here's how:

1. Make your graham cracker crust. Any ol' recipe will do. Mine was ad-lib.

2. Pat it into the pie pan (9", please), and stick it in the fridge. Meanwhile..

3. Whip up your PB mousse in the food processor! I used this one, except halving the PB for a lighter taste. Oh, also make only 1/2 the recipe since you want chocolate too! Scoop out into a bowl.

4. Now make the chocolate part! I used a modification of this recipe, (halved, of course!) although. It's one of my absolute favorite decadent desserts and there are different variations all over the interwebs.

5. Put alternating dollops of both mousses into the prepared crust.

6. Now swirl it up!

7. To take it over the top, drizzle liberally with melted chocolate! Now, cover with plastic wrap and put the whole shebang back in the fridge for at least 2-3 hours, or until ready to serve.

8. ENJOY! Celebrate Pi Day!

item.title: Aaaaand.... She's Back!
item.dc:creator: sophie
item.content:encoded: First of all -- if you've landed here via my old url, www.mpetitchou.com -- no worries! This isn't a sneaky phishing scheme; you've come to the right place :) Visitors new and old -- welcome to my food blog! Pika Chews is the mnemonic-friendly version of my old food blog, Mon Petit Chou. All old posts still exist here, so no worries if you wanted to revisit some of my old recipes (or high-school writing). After putting food blogging on hiatus due to an incredibly busy Junior year in college, and doing a short stunt on Tumblr, I'm back, to welcome in this summer (the season of barbeques, dining al fresco, and best of all, ICE CREAM) by blogging with renewed aplomb! What's new in the new blog? Not much! My goal is to produce more quality writing in my posts. As I do live in NYC, in addition to recipes, I'll be focusing on more reviews of eateries and coffeeshops around the city, since I frequent many! What's on the plate for Pika? For fun and a little anticipation, here are some summer food-blogging projects i've got in mind! 1. A coffee tour of NYC As a computer scientist with a lot of STEM field friends, there's one thing we all adore: CAFFEINE! More specifically, the good stuff: coffee. As I am lucky to live in a city filled with independent and artisinal coffeeshops, not just the Green Mermaid, I'm going to do my best to keep track of all the caffeinated adventures, both store-brewed and home-ground. 2. A Chocolate Croissant Tour of NYC a.k.a. the Chocodex Anyone who knows me knows that I have a humongous sweet tooth. My latest fixation? Chocolate croissants! The goal: to find and index all the pain au chocolat I nom. Bon Appetit! 3. Homemade Ice Cream I am absolutely ice-cream obsessed so it's high time I tried making my own! Will I succeed? Will I fail? Keep reading to find out. Suggestions, comments, concerns? Drop a comment!
